context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 76-011, Adamo Wrecking Co. against the United States will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In this case, the United States criminally prosecuted the petitioner, Adamo Wrecking Co. in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan for failure to comply with an emission standard which had been issued by the administrator under the Clean Air Act.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The District Court dismissed the indictment, concluding that the regulation was not an emission standard within the meaning of the term as used by Congress in the Act.

Adamo Wrecking Company v. United States.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Adamo Wrecking Company v. United States.case_name: Adamo Wrecking Company v. United States
Adamo Wrecking Company v. United States.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 10, 1978

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The District Court in our opinion properly concluded that this regulation, dictating particular work practices to be followed in the demolition of buildings was not such a standard.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The language and history of the Act demonstrate that Congress intended emission standards to be quantitative limitations on emissions of particular pollutants.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The District Court's judgment of dismissing the indictment was therefore proper and the judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: While joining the opinion of the Court, Mr. Justice Powell has filed a separate concurrence.

context.text: My consent and what prompts me to speak at this length in dissent, is not so much that this petitioner has made a mockery of the system of justice, rather is that this Court has construed a statute in a way that invites and rewards falsehood.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Until today's decision, no, under today's decision, every person who is subject to deportation has it within his power by presenting transparently false testimony to obtain both protracted, administrative, and judicial proceedings extending over years.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The Court today has opened a unique and inviting door.

Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.speaker: Justice Burger
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.case_name: Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spannaus
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 25, 1978

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Suppose in the statute they had a formula, a pattern and they just required all companies to start putting their money into these funds?

context.speaker: George B. Christensen
context.text: Well, that Your Honor, I do not think would involve the obligation of contracts clause.

context.speaker: George B. Christensen
context.text: It involves questions of due process.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Is that very far away from what the Social Security Act as Mr. Justice White’s suggestion?

context.speaker: George B. Christensen
context.text: Well, it is not too far away from it, but Your Honor, your point now is addressed to the powers of the Federal Government and it is not directed to destroying or altering or changing a private contract.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What you are suggesting is that the Federal Government is not bound by the retirement clause the way the states are?

Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.speaker: Justice White
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.case_name: Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spannaus
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 25, 1978

context.speaker: George B. Christensen
context.text: If you follow social security, a state would tax individuals and employers in some prescribed amount to build retirement payments at age 65 or with the permission of this Court now 70 whatever it may be.

context.speaker: George B. Christensen
context.text: Now, that is quite a different problem, Mr. Justice. That retroactively is saying to employees who have worked and have received ever dime they were entitled to, either in direct wages or in the written promises or fringe benefits such as this pension plan.

context.speaker: George B. Christensen
context.text: You would go back and pay more money to those people by a sort of a retroactive vesting.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Christensen, are there not really two parts to the retroactive aspect of this case, Mr. Justice Rehnquist’s question brought this to mind.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: On the one hand you have to put more money into the fund, you come up with more and secondly, you are prevented from getting back that which you would have been able to recover over and above the vested rights of those who are entitled to some money that I take it were in the surplus that under the contract, you would have had the right to return?

context.speaker: George B. Christensen
context.text: No.

Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.speaker: Justice White
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.case_name: Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spannaus
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 25, 1978

context.speaker: George B. Christensen
context.text: Now of course, contributions made five years ago on behalf of employee 'A' who died in the interim, stay in the fund and help fund or provide money for employee C, D and so forth, but it does not revert back to the employer.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But if you terminate the plan --

context.speaker: George B. Christensen
context.text: No sir --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: That you are asserting that in answer to Mr. Justice Rehnquist, you pointed out that the contractual right to terminate the plan had been impaired.

context.speaker: George B. Christensen
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But how did that hurt you then if all the money was in there to stay anyway?

Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.speaker: Justice White
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.case_name: Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spannaus
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 25, 1978

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But that is not an impairment of an existing obligation.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: That is a creation of a new obligation?

context.speaker: George B. Christensen
context.text: Well, or it is a condition.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And your answer to Mr. Justice Rehnquist was that, well, they have impaired our right to cancel the plan, now how did that hurt you, the no longer being able to cancel the plan?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I thought that meant that you would have gotten some money back.

context.speaker: George B. Christensen
context.text: I do not think a conditional right to cancel it.

Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.case_name: Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spannaus
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 25, 1978

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What you are saying in effect is you can impair so far as the employer is concerned, but not so far as the employee is concerned?

context.speaker: Byron E. Starns
context.text: Well, that maybe the case Your Honor.

context.speaker: Byron E. Starns
context.text: I think we are talking about what the public purpose of this statute is the first benchmark of analysis, what is the public purpose?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What if the Minnesota legislature had decided that most Minnesota manufacturing companies had put much too much money into pension funding for their financial stability, and therefore, it was of great importance to the State to enable them to reduce these commitments, and therefore, it adopted the provision that Justice White proposed to you.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Do you think that would be impairment?

context.speaker: Byron E. Starns
context.text: I think it may not, if the Court were to accept those situations as constituting a sufficient fact for public purpose.

Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.speaker: Justice Burger
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.case_name: Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spannaus
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 26, 1978

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and the opinion of the Court in 77-747, Allied Structural Steel Company against Spannaus, the attorney general of Minnesota will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here on direct appeal from the United States District Court for the district of Minnesota.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This is an important case, both as a matter of abstract constitutional law and as a matter of practical impact and I shall make only a very brief oral announcement this morning.

Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.speaker: Justice Stewart
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.case_name: Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spannaus
Allied Structural Steel Company v. Spann.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 26, 1978

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The question presented is whether the application of Minnesota's Private Pension Benefits Protection Act to the appellant company violates the contract clause of the Constitution.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This is the constitutional provision that was at issue in the famous Darmouth College case, argued here by Daniel Webster more than a 150 years ago, but it is a constitutional provision that has been largely quiescent in this century.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in detail in the written opinion of the Court we conclude that the Minnesota law does violate this provision of the constitution, accordingly the judgment is reversed.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this case, and Mr. Justice Brennan has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall have joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Thomas W. O'Toole
context.text: And found that all of the Indians prosecuted in the Federal Court should be treated equally as any other defendant prosecutors in Federal Court and then recently in this Court's opinion in Antelope, the court again as I indicated earlier said that the Indian tribes were once sovereign and that any attributes of sovereignty and powers of self government were the result of the exercise of this Congress’s and the Federal Government’s plenary authority in pertinence of the word guarding relationship that exists between the tribes and the Federal Government.

context.text: Cannot that be read as meaning such sovereignty as the Congress has allowed them to retain?

context.text: Well again Your Honor semantically I do not think the words sovereignty for purposes of this case is an appropriate means of describing that particular relationship.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here by way of a writ of certiorari granted to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The question presented by the case is whether the Double Jeopardy Clause of the Fifth Amendment bars the prosecution of an Indian in a Federal District Court when he has previously been convicted in a tribal court of a lesser included offense arising out of the same criminal episode.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in detail in the written opinion of the Court filed today with the clerk, we have concluded that the power to punish offenses against Tribal law committed by members of the Navajos tribe is based upon the Navajos' primeval sovereignty, that this power has never been taken away from them, and that it is attributable in no way to any delegation to them of federal authority.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It follows that when the Navajo Tribe exercises this power, it does so as part of its retained sovereignty and not as an arm of the Federal Government.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed.

context.text: Under traditional Fourth Amendment law, the Fourth Amendment has permitted warrants to search property on which there is probable cause to believe, there is located fruits, instrumentalities, or evidence of a crime regardless of who owns the property.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We decline to adopt this rather sweeping revision of the Fourth Amendment and accordingly, have filed an opinion disagreeing with the Court of Appeals in this respect.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The lower courts also held that whatever the rule might be generally with respect to Third - so called third-party searches, where the third-party isn't suspected of crime, that a search warrant should not issue, but a subpoena duces tecum should be used when the third party is a newspaper, that is when the premises to be searched is occupied by a newspaper.

context.text: We also disagree with this narrower holding and in our view, the whatever First Amendment considerations, there might be in a situation like this can be satisfactorily accommodated by a careful application of the usual criteria governing the issue of search warrants.
